document.title: New York State 3-5 Science Learning Standards

F8C00A6332BE40DDBADCCF6632590E3C.description: (NYSED) Engineers improve existing technologies or develop new ones to increase their benefits (e.g., improved Doppler radar), decrease known risks (e.g., severe weather alerts), and meet societal demands (e.g., cell phone applications). (3-ESS3-1)

5E36A5C34D1A4F42AAE914976BDA0E50.description: Influence of Engineering, Technology, and Science on Society and the Natural World

8F67032201E141DE9B20BE5341CF2919.description: Cause and effect relationships are routinely identified, tested, and used to explain change. (3-ESS2-3),(3-ESS3-1)

4F4D59CDB4064B72896D3FD9DAD9D1A2.description: Patterns of change can be used to make predictions. (3-ESS2-1),(3-ESS2- 2)

EE2C65C345424F16AB8C9933187E315C.description: A variety of natural hazards result from natural processes. Humans cannot eliminate natural hazards but can take steps to reduce their impacts. (3-ESS3-1) (Note: This Disciplinary Core Idea is also addressed by 4-ESS3-2)

0EC856EEAF67463F9E786D3C2A3C379D.description: (NYSED) Earthâ€™s processes continuously cycle water, contributing to weather and climate. (3-ESS2-3)

1DD0473A5C8041DDA87EA242D38A747A.description: Climate describes a range of an area's typical weather conditions and the extent to which those conditions vary over years. (3-ESS2-2)

EE54FDD583AB4A04804BF68266E009E9.description: Scientists record patterns of the weather across different times and areas so that they can make predictions about what kind of weather might happen next. (3-ESS2-1)

54514DC3EBB54359B777F507C65ABEB1.description: Obtain and combine information from books and other reliable media to explain phenomena. (3-ESS2-2)

DE2EF5A2F924496D9A15A4C9C59FE869.description: Make a claim about the merit of a solution to a problem by citing relevant evidence about how it meets the criteria and constraints of the problem. (3-ESS3-1)

A769A7E067944561AB4C78554CC372FC.description: Represent data in tables and various graphical displays (bar graphs and pictographs) to reveal patterns that indicate relationships. (3-ESS2-1)

3E69F6CFFAF1493385B0E785F6E1EEA5.description: Make observations and/or measurements to produce data to serve as the basis for evidence for an explanation of a phenomenon or test a design solution. (3-ESS2-3)

0BA66053FCA84EBAA9450C8B8D30B89A.description: Plan and conduct an investigation collaboratively to produce data to serve as the basis for evidence, using fair tests in which variables are controlled and the number of trials considered. (3-ESS2-3)

63281354C7F442AE852110AAB097FF37.description: Plan and conduct an investigation to determine the connections between weather and water processes in Earth systems.

0C329BEAA05A4BFC8AC33BFCCE3C9F84.description: Make a claim about the merit of a design solution that reduces the impacts of a weather-related hazard.

3E99A3C1DA3A43B5B3B9D8C87FCCC990.description: Obtain and combine information to describe climates in different regions of the world.

3EC3FC81120142BFA80956EAAD2DA3F0.description: Represent data in tables and graphical displays to describe typical weather conditions expected during a particular season.

7A8B6E2AB4C14400A9359C3C161DA4E9.description: Cause and effect relationships are routinely identified and used to explain change. (3-LS3- 2),(3-LS4-2)

B8B80F9553A742919995AA76812A68CB.description: Patterns of change can be used to make predictions. (3- LS1-1)

5C2389AEC707410A8DCFCAEED335281B.description: Similarities and differences in patterns can be used to sort and classify natural phenomena. (3-LS3-1)

EF0B0A94AD50463B8E5CD44618DD092D.description: Sometimes the differences in characteristics between individuals of the same species provide advantages in surviving, finding mates, and reproducing. (3-LS4-2)

7A18503CF9474702AD364B588439454A.description: The environment also affects the traits that an organism develops. (3-LS3-2)

79593F15C3884C7CAB3676F835A3470C.description: Different organisms vary in how they look and function because they have different inherited information. (3-LS3-1)

C2BFE03D5C3444C189A85546EFB1B302.description: (NYSED) Some characteristics result from the interactions of both inheritance and the effect of the environment. (3-LS3-2)

B03CB21014FF4EE7A784160CB31D6BA3.description: Other characteristics result from individualsâ€™ interactions with the environment, which can range from diet to learning. (3-LS3-2)

B6A638B9B2D746088EB26A7E955A7944.description: Many characteristics of organisms are inherited from their parents. (3-LS3-1)

D432E24374294FA2876449651E24340C.description: Reproduction is essential to the continued existence of every kind of organism. Plants and animals have unique and diverse life cycles. (3-LS1-1)

4216EF2E55204DD0968ACA240A6BD59E.description: LS1.B: Growth and Development of Organisms

28F374CD1524475BA9A2D92C2D6D3085.description: Science findings are based on recognizing patterns. (3-LS1-1)

96B074078CB84822AE6BF21A41B06ED3.description: Scientific Knowledge is Based on Empirical Evidence

C553876CE75F4A12B984C521B9747BFF.description: Use evidence (e.g., observations, patterns) to construct an explanation. (3-LS4-2)

05CAD4FC2C124C0B8CAA9BBCF765F089.description: Use evidence (e.g., observations, patterns) to support an explanation. (3-LS3-2)

097CB104848141A892DD057CAD25D972.description: Analyze and interpret data to make sense of phenomena using logical reasoning. (3-LS3-1)

B70582A956CF4E99B4322B95CCD92FEB.description: Use evidence to construct an explanation for how the variations in characteristics among individuals of the same species may provide advantages in surviving, finding mates, and reproducing.

568E2F084C584CB7A3FE75DFA90AB59B.description: Use evidence to support the explanation that traits can be influenced by the environment.

D3B0549B41F24D208447F581AC0F6FA3.description: Analyze and interpret data to provide evidence that plants and animals have traits inherited from parents and that variation of these traits exists in a group of similar organisms.

E701679C282E4A4986FD8F81AF51CC8B.description: Develop models to describe that organisms have unique and diverse life cycles but all have in common birth, growth, reproduction, and death.

238C3E46B6724E17A12CC72402B8D2A5.description: 3. Inheritance and Variation of Traits: Life Cycles and Traits

9E313890FB7E4783A3B955E24AA87215.description: Science assumes consistent patterns in natural systems. (3- LS4-1)

803CDCEE044A41DABAEB844FB8309D1C.description: Scientific Knowledge Assumes an Order and Consistency in Natural Systems

E26804EA15E546808D11BE571DAB769B.description: Knowledge of relevant scientific concepts and research findings is important in engineering. (3-LS4-4)

25A8A97FD9B741119A45BDA5337F1235.description: Interdependence of Science, Engineering, and Technology

F699DC90DAE148CA895692ED63CD8DF5.description: A system can be described in terms of its components and their interactions. (3-LS4-4)

E0FB2E6FBB0848AE901A072BD69FD3E5.description: Observable phenomena exist from very short to very long time periods. (3-LS4-1)

D93A4B78C5E04AD08C2D8601F0C927C3.description: Cause and effect relationships are routinely identified and used to explain change. (3-LS2-1),(3-LS4-3)

38E3C47D42304A17BDC3B0C040C05399.description: Populations live in a variety of habitats, and change in those habitats affects the organisms living there. (3-LS4-4)

C6F8DE7364774E188B4919077E172465.description: For any particular environment, some kinds of organisms survive well, some survive less well, and some cannot survive at all. (3-LS4-3

AFE8CD3EC6594078A21BFCCDBE8C76D1.description: Fossils provide evidence about the types of organisms that lived long ago and also about the nature of their environments. (3- LS4-1)

0B84E0F60B364F43A26A1C0737633DFA.description: Some kinds of plants and animals that once lived on Earth are no longer found anywhere. (Note: Moved from Kâ€“2) (3-LS4-1)

643ABA2DA52842C5819DCF0E617523BC.description: LS4.A: Evidence of Common Ancestry and Diversity

E7417583E20D4F9BB19D487529342888.description: (NYSED) Being part of a group helps some animals obtain food, defend themselves, and survive. Groups may serve different functions and vary dramatically in size. (Note: Moved from Kâ€“2) (3-LS2-1)

A5EE93B237E04EE19801C4961CB2D5D6.description: LS2.D: Social Interactions and Group Behavior

23B21769FE244437B1A01C7390983E4F.description: When the environment changes in ways that affect a placeâ€™s physical characteristics, temperature, or availability of resources, some organisms survive and reproduce, others move to new locations, yet others move into the transformed environment, and some die. (secondary to 3-LS4-4)

BD0DDC2CFBD1458BBD6DE8314AF5131E.description: LS2.C: Ecosystem Dynamics, Functioning, and Resilience

D502857D7F28462EBD1FE253B2E20FF7.description: Make a claim about the merit of a solution to a problem by citing relevant evidence about how it meets the criteria and constraints of the problem. (3-LS4-4)

B344FBDF393744C59E7718BB5D467E5F.description: Construct an argument with evidence, data, and/or a model. (3-LS2-1)

897F2D14B7184A30B3F38FA5CE003CA7.description: Analyze and interpret data to make sense of phenomena using logical reasoning. (3-LS4-1)

88ECB613434446958882C8E108A1FCF5.description: Make a claim about the merit of a solution to a problem caused when the environment changes and the types of plants and animals that live there may change.

C2C5A825C8EB4A4396CA5A566F9F44E6.description: Construct an argument with evidence that in a particular habitat some organisms can survive well, some survive less well, and some cannot survive at all.

8BE19D526A244534805CDC4C073F8167.description: Analyze and interpret data from fossils to provide evidence of the organisms and the environments in which they lived long ago.

C984D0D927054A15A8643ABB82AB9EDF.description: Construct an argument that some animals form groups that help members survive.

B2DA8EEA71104C078A611EC3D2366CD5.description: Scientific discoveries about the natural world can often lead to new and improved technologies, which are developed through the engineering design process. (3- PS2-4)

9195ACC64D784F15ABD5329E35BF62EB.description: Interdependence of Science, Engineering, and Technology

12A5EEF6285C4BECB1E7EE41362403DD.description: Cause and effect relationships are routinely identified, tested, and used to explain change. (3-PS2-3)

324AB287C7704DCDA26461735987A063.description: Cause and effect relationships are routinely identified. (3- PS2-1)

077B2455939347CC9DD4B7B9A2661AE0.description: Patterns of change can be used to make predictions. (3-PS2-2)

462DA5954F3C4FEAA546DE637EC4FE68.description: Electric and magnetic forces between a pair of objects do not require that the objects be in contact. The sizes of the forces in each situation depend on the properties of the objects and their distances apart and, for forces between two magnets, on their orientation relative to each other. (3-PS2-3),(3-PS2-4)

CBFC1878FACC459B8AA840A290585DC0.description: Objects in contact exert forces on each other. (3-PS2-1)

69D121DE6DD045F28AE4794EA930ACB4.description: The patterns of an objectâ€™s motion in various situations can be observed and measured; when that past motion exhibits a regular pattern, future motion can be predicted from it. (Boundary: Technical terms, such as magnitude, velocity, momentum, and vector quantity, are not introduced at this level, but the concept that some quantities need both size and direction to be described is developed.) (3-PS2-2)

7BB347FD99EE486B8E72D4A83D620219.description: Each force acts on one particular object and has both strength and a direction. An object at rest typically has multiple forces acting on it, but they add to give zero net force on the object. Forces that do not sum to zero can cause changes in the objectâ€™s speed or direction of motion. (Boundary: Qualitative and conceptual, but not quantitative addition of forces are used at this level.) (3- PS2-1)

E7458B9D22D44861B7AD452FA1493414.description: Science investigations use a variety of methods, tools, and techniques. (3-PS2-1)

2395C27E70B74F539B03B8387E4D36C0.description: Scientific Investigations Use a Variety of Methods

55876D859F1F4F249E28417A44067684.description: Science findings are based on recognizing patterns. (3- PS2-2)

4CF78281730441DEA1C13D59BB105B76.description: Science Knowledge is Based on Empirical Evidence

F20B3240ADEC458797794739914F66DC.description: Make observations and/or measurements to produce data to serve as the basis for evidence for an explanation of a phenomenon or test a design solution. (3-PS2-2)

D6B7D22FBC4D414BA399CE5B9D697EFD.description: Plan and conduct an investigation collaboratively to produce data to serve as the basis for evidence, using fair tests in which variables are controlled and the number of trials considered. (3-PS2-1)

D6AACCB423E349C0BC9F4087F02ED174.description: Define a simple problem that can be solved through the development of a new or improved object or tool. (3- PS2-4)

E61F074420EB400F90C4EDBC8BE0F70D.description: Ask questions that can be investigated based on patterns such as cause and effect relationships. (3- PS2-3)

5CA9EAA23CBA40C5B568470D877EAF98.description: Define a simple design problem that can be solved by applying scientific ideas about magnets.

0F3A7D7E19B84A8EA3920FC3E43DBC5A.description: Ask questions to determine cause and effect relationships of electric or magnetic interactions between two objects not in contact with each other

18FF3D65C9214A3BA728A3CAA856DF07.description: Make observations and/or measurements of an objectâ€™s motion to provide evidence that a pattern can be used to predict future motion.

AE4DF554A41048969358D8DB859A6467.description: Plan and conduct an investigation to provide evidence of the effects of balanced and unbalanced forces on the motion of an object.

39AB4945799D46B6A68367DDC7953F26.description: Engineers improve existing technologies or develop new ones to increase their benefits, decrease known risks, and meet societal demands. (3-5-ETS1-2)

98721CAA7B6845E884B8E2272AE0AB02.description: Peopleâ€™s needs and wants change over time, as do their demands for new and improved technologies. (3-5-ETS1-1)

C03A6D7A7B59463AA64DC28251039527.description: Influence of Science, Engineering, and Technology on Society and the Natural World

872C5C9829844F28A7CE4066F002A30B.description: Different solutions need to be tested in order to determine which of them best solves the problem, given the criteria and the constraints. (3-5-ETS1-3)

ABB41FBD38FE48509F6F18D50361C985.description: Tests are often designed to identify failure points or difficulties, which suggest the elements of the design that need to be improved. (3-5-ETS1-3)

2188A9028167493880E079488D79703F.description: At whatever stage, communicating with peers about proposed solutions is an important part of the design process, and shared ideas can lead to improved designs. (3-5-ETS1-2)

9F3F97A578D94A11AB9D334B1B9DE75C.description: Research on a problem should be carried out before beginning to design a solution. Testing a solution involves investigating how well it performs under a range of likely conditions. (3-5-ETS1-2)

F5E8CAF6167E47DBA808C36ED8902F41.description: Possible solutions to a problem are limited by available materials and resources (constraints). The success of a designed solution is determined by considering the desired features of a solution (criteria). Different proposals for solutions can be compared on the basis of how well each one meets the specified criteria for success or how well each takes the constraints into account. (3-5-ETS1-1)

EF96F2B8B68348B9A0BCEBADD496487A.description: ETS1.A: Defining and Delimiting Engineering Problems

09FD1B52DC744B8482C2CB9D194E9A52.description: Generate and compare multiple solutions to a problem based on how well they meet the criteria and constraints of the design problem. (3-5-ETS1- 2)

27E74786843D438FA07B63CF1F6F517C.description: Plan and conduct an investigation collaboratively to produce data to serve as the basis for evidence, using fair tests in which variables are controlled and the number of trials considered. (3-5-ETS1-3)

51ADFE37D20442EA84033813A2659FF0.description: Define a simple design problem that can be solved through the development of an object, tool, process, or system and includes several criteria for success and constraints on materials, time, or cost. (3-5- ETS1-1)

82F4E04314FD4B5BB84289FA268DD784.description: Plan and carry out fair tests in which variables are controlled and failure points are considered to identify aspects of a model or prototype that can be improved.

DF22124FB74F4E04B96D1DBE11C6B829.description: Generate and compare multiple possible solutions to a problem based on how well each is likely to meet the criteria and constraints of the problem.

AC3F6105DE314D24A3D10AC24AD53CAD.description: Define a simple design problem reflecting a need or a want that includes specified criteria for success and constraints on materials, time, or cost.
